ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: All the basic microeconomics things: supply and demand, theory of the consumer, market structures, and a little bit of game theory. I guess in some sense it can help you understand the world better, but honestly most of the general 'rules' you learn are very intuitive!

I developed a good basis in microeconomics. We covered all the important material and as I leave the course, I feel that I have a really developed understanding of the theory behind all the economic concepts we learned, not just that I can regurgitate an answer I learned in class.
Basic understanding of introductory microeconomics
I gained a deeper understanding of microeconomics.
Prof Reiche is a wonderful professor.  She is patient and really cares about your learning.

I improved my own decision-making skills while learning how economists view decisions of individual firms in a market. I was introduced to many new, important terms, such as elasticity of demand and externalities, which help me think about my own purchasing power.
As the course name suggests, I learned the basics of microeconomics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It's good for what it is!

Strengths: not too much work. Psets pretty easy. Nice professor who cares about her students. 
Weaknesses: not very interesting. feels like a bunch of meaningless abstractions and excessive confusing notation
More real-world examples and concept mapping to help us really internalize the content.
The lectures were information and to-the-point, but they were relatively dry. I would have liked to see the professor make a better effort to connect the material to modern-day economic events

My engagement was only "medium" because I had 4 other, somewhat intense classes to focus on. Each concept was thoroughly explained and helped me feel confident in my ability to follow economic discussions outside of class.

Strengths: The course provides an introductory survey of microeconomics, which covers a lot of topics over the course of the semester
Weaknesses: If these concepts are new to you, this course can be overwhelming. It is very fast-paced, and I found it is very easy to fall behind with the material.
I loved the seminar structure of the course, very personal feel in every class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, mostly if you want to take higher level economics. It's not like a cool history class where you'll be wowed just by the course itself, it's much more of a low-key building block. Not that it's bad, it's just not fun or exciting.
yes, the small setting is really helpful when you want to make sure you can engage with the material

I just don't like econ that much I think, so take it with a grain of salt, but no I wouldn't. I don't think this class contributed very substantively to my understanding of the world/life nor did it teach me a useful skillset. I think those two reasons are the best reasons to take classes. This was overcomplicated abstractions of what seems like inaccurate assessments (or at least oversimplified) of human decision-making. If you're taking econ as a major, I suppose you should take this class, it's probably a necessary prereq, and I hear other econ classes get more interesting and concrete. But I wouldn't recommend this to fulfill QR requirements.
Absolutely. Professor Reiche was an amazing teacher who always came to class with excellent slides prepared to teach us.
Yes under the circumstance theyd be okay with a B, as thats the average grade! I learned a lot, but at the expense of many mistakes.
Yes. I have never taken an econ class. This was a good well paced introduction
Please dont take the seminarit might seem as a engaging way to digest the material more thoroughly, but the competition is fiercer and you cant really be off your game at any point in the semester.
I would recommend this course to a student, whether they wanted to learn more about devision-making or economics generally. It's a good introduction to both!
I would only recommend this course if the student in question had a high level of interest in the subject, as the workload and material can be challenging.

It depends. If you have been exposed to econ before or feel confident in your economic abilities, then yes. A lot of the information will probably be familiar to you. If you have never taken econ before and/or do not feel economically inclined, then no. I found that the people who tend to take this class have all already taken econ in some measure in high school. The curve will not be in your favor. From what I understand, the lecture is better in this regard.
Yes hundred percent, the professor is amazing.
